content: The Act is titled the "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" and is based on Congress's authority to regulate commerce and make necessary laws. It addresses identity theft. The Act "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" amends Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for knowingly transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority for unlawful activities. The Act "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" amends Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for identity theft involving the transfer or use of identification to obtain anything of value over $1,000 in a year. Penalties include fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both for offenses related to drug trafficking, violent crimes, or repeat offenses. The Act "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" amends Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for identity theft involving the transfer or use of identification to obtain anything of value over $1,000 in a year. Penalties now include forfeiture of any personal property used in the offense and amendments to definitions and circumstances related to interstate commerce and transportation of identification documents. The United States Code is amended to define terms related to identification documents and document-making implements. The term 'document-making implement' refers to tools used for creating identification documents. 'Identification document' is defined as a document issued by a government entity for identifying individuals. 'Means of identification' includes names and numbers used to identify individuals. The United States Code is amended to define terms related to identification documents and document-making implements. The term 'personal identification card' means an identification document issued by a State or local government solely for the purpose of identification. The term 'produce' includes alter, authenticate, or assemble. The term 'State' includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, and any other commonwealth, possession, or territory of the United States. The United States Code is amended to include provisions on attempt and conspiracy, forfeiture procedures, and a rule of construction related to identification documents and document-making implements. The United States Code is amended to include a rule of construction regarding identification documents containing means of identification. Amendments are made to Chapter 47 of title 18, adding "and information" to the heading and table of sections for section 1028. AMENDMENT OF FEDERAL SENTENCING GUIDELINES FOR OFFENSES UNDER SECTION 1028. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to establish appropriate penalties for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors for consideration include the number of victims and means of identification involved in the offense. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to establish appropriate penalties for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors for consideration include the value of the loss to individuals, range of conduct covered, sentencing enhancements, statutory maximum penalties, achieving sentencing purposes, and any other relevant factors. The Federal Trade Commission will establish a centralized complaint and consumer education service for victims of identity theft. This service will log complaints, provide information to individuals, and refer complaints to appropriate entities, including consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement agencies. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this service. SEC. 6. Technical amendments to Title 18, United States Code include a correction related to criminal forfeiture procedures and the inclusion of economic espionage and theft of trade secrets as predicate offenses for wire interception. Section 105(b) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to allow for redaction of reports filed by individuals described in specific sections of the Act if revealing personal information could endanger them. The redaction is only permitted to protect the individual and must be maintained as long as the danger exists. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts is required to submit an annual report to the Committees on the Judiciary detailing the operation of this provision. The Judicial Conference, in consultation with the Department of Justice, will issue regulations for redaction of reports to protect individuals from threats.
